answer_llm: The parameter count for a Conv2d layer is determined by the formula (3*3*3 + 1) * 32, which equals 896. The number of "features" obtained after the Flatten layer comes from the calculation 7*7*128, which equals 6272.
answer_orig:
Let’s say we define our Conv2d layer like this:
>> tf.keras.layers.Conv2D(32, (3,3), activation='relu', input_shape=(150, 150, 3))
It means our input image is RGB (3 channels, 150 by 150 pixels), kernel is 3x3 and number of filters (layer’s width) is 32.
If we check model.summary() we will get this:
_________________________________________________________________
Layer (type)                Output Shape              Param #
=================================================================
conv2d (Conv2D)             (None, 148, 148, 32)      896
So where does 896 params come from? It’s computed like this:
>>> (3*3*3 +1) * 32
896
# 3x3 kernel, 3 channels RGB, +1 for bias, 32 filters
What about the number of “features” we get after the Flatten layer?
For our homework model.summary() for last MaxPooling2d and Flatten layers looked like this:
_________________________________________________________________
Layer (type)                Output Shape              Param #
=================================================================
max_pooling2d_3       (None, 7, 7, 128)         0
flatten (Flatten)           (None, 6272)              0
So where do 6272 vectors come from? It’s computed like this:
>>> 7*7*128
6272
# 7x7 “image shape” after several convolutions and poolings, 128 filters
Added by Andrii Larkin
question: What determines the parameter count for a Conv2d layer?

answer_llm:
The output shape of a Conv2d layer is derived based on the input image size, kernel size, and number of filters. For example, if we define a Conv2d layer with a kernel size of 3x3 and 32 filters for an RGB image of size 150x150 pixels, the output shape would be (None, 148, 148, 32) as shown in model.summary(). The number of parameters for the Conv2d layer is computed as (3*3*3 + 1) * 32 = 896. 

The number of "features" obtained after the Flatten layer is calculated based on the dimensions of the output of the last pooling layer. For example, if the output shape after the last MaxPooling2d layer is (None, 7, 7, 128), then the number of features after the Flatten layer would be 7*7*128 = 6272.

answer_llm: The main difference between the Sequential Model API and the Functional Model API in Keras is the way in which the layers are added to the model. In the Sequential Model API, you can easily start with an empty model and add layers in a sequential order, which makes it easier to work with a sequence of similar layers. On the other hand, the Functional Model API allows for a more complicated way of implementing the model, which can be useful when doing Transfer Learning and separating different parts of the model.
answer_orig:
It’s quite useful to understand that all types of models in the course are a plain stack of layers where each layer has exactly one input tensor and one output tensor (Sequential model TF page, Sequential class).
You can simply start from an “empty” model and add more and more layers in a sequential order.
This mode is called “Sequential Model API”  (easier)
In Alexey’s videos it is implemented as chained calls of different entities (“inputs”,“base”, “vectors”,  “outputs”) in a more advanced mode “Functional Model API”.
Maybe a more complicated way makes sense when you do Transfer Learning and want to separate “Base” model vs. rest, but in the HW you need to recreate the full model from scratch ⇒ I believe it is easier to work with a sequence of “similar” layers.
You can read more about it in this TF2 tutorial.
A really useful Sequential model example is shared in the Kaggle’s “Bee or Wasp” dataset folder with code: notebook
Added by Ivan Brigida
Fresh Run on Neural Nets
While correcting an error on neural net architecture, it is advised to do fresh run by restarting kernel, else the model learns on top of previous runs.
Added by Abhijit Chakraborty

answer_llm:
To fix out of memory errors in TensorFlow when using an Nvidia GPU, you can try using the following code snippet:
```
physical_devices = tf.config.list_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
    tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0], True)
except:
    # Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized.
    pass
```
answer_orig:
I found this code snippet fixed my OOM errors, as I have an Nvidia GPU. Can't speak to OOM errors on CPU, though.
https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/config/experimental/set_memory_growth
```
physical_devices = tf.configlist_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0],True)
except:
# Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized.
pass
```
question: What steps should I take to fix out of memory errors in TensorFlow when using an Nvidia GPU?

answer_llm:
To address out of memory errors in TensorFlow when not using a CPU, you can try setting the memory growth for your GPU using the code snippet below:

```python
physical_devices = tf.config.list_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
    tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0], True)
except:
    # Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized.
    pass
```

This code should help in fixing the OOM errors specifically for Nvidia GPUs.

answer_llm: To speed up model training on Google Colab with a T4 GPU, you can change the number of workers/threads in the fit function. Specify a higher number of workers, such as 2560, to improve the performance. This change was found to be very helpful in speeding up training with the T4 GPU on Google Colab.
answer_orig:

The number of threads apparently also works for GPUs, and came very handy in google colab for the T4 GPU, since it was very very slow, and workers default value is 1.

answer_llm: ImageDataGenerator is not recommended for new code in Keras because it has been deprecated. It is advised to use tf.keras.utils.image_dataset_from_directory and transform the output tf.data.Dataset with preprocessing layers instead.
answer_orig:
From the keras documentation:
Deprecated: tf.keras.preprocessing.image.ImageDataGenerator is not recommended for new code. Prefer loading images with tf.keras.utils.image_dataset_from_directory and transforming the output tf.data.Dataset with preprocessing layers. For more information, see the tutorials for loading images and augmenting images, as well as the preprocessing layer guide.
Hrithik Kumar Advani

answer_llm: When the command echo ${REMOTE_URI} returns nothing, it means that the URI address was not properly set in the local variable REMOTE_URI. You need to set the local variable by assigning your URI address in the terminal, for example, REMOTE_URI=2278222782.dkr.ecr.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images (fake address). Make sure to replace REMOTE_URI with your actual URI.
answer_orig:
Solution description
In the unit 9.6, Alexey ran the command echo ${REMOTE_URI} which turned the URI address in the terminal. There workaround is to set a local variable (REMOTE_URI) and assign your URI address in the terminal and use it to login the registry, for instance, REMOTE_URI=2278222782.dkr.ecr.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images (fake address). One caveat is that you will lose this variable once the session is terminated.
I also had the same problem on Ubuntu terminal. I executed the following two commands:
$ export REMOTE_URI=1111111111.dkr.ecr.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images:clothing-model-xception-v4-001
$ echo $REMOTE_URI
111111111.dkr.ecr.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images:clothing-model-xception-v4-001
Note: 1. no curly brackets (e.g. echo ${REMOTE_URI}) needed unlike in video 9.6,
2. Replace REMOTE_URI with your URI
(Bhaskar Sarma)
question: What does it mean when the command echo ${REMOTE_URI} returns nothing?

answer_llm:
To set the REMOTE_URI variable to your URI address, you need to run the following command:

$ export REMOTE_URI=your_URI_address

For example:
$ export REMOTE_URI=1111111111.dkr.ecr.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images:clothing-model-xception-v4-001

After running this command, you can check if the variable was set correctly by running the command:

$ echo $REMOTE_URI

Remember that you don't need curly brackets when echoing the REMOTE_URI variable.

answer_llm: The updated command to fetch the password from aws-cli when the original returns an invalid choice error is: aws ecr get-login-password
answer_orig:
The command aws ecr get-login --no-include-email returns an invalid choice error:
The solution is to use the following command instead:  aws ecr get-login-password
Could simplify the login process with, just replace the <ACCOUNT_NUMBER> and <REGION> with your values:
export PASSWORD=`aws ecr get-login-password`
docker login -u AWS -p $PASSWORD <ACCOUNT_NUMBER>.dkr.ecr.<REGION>.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images
Added by Martin Uribe

answer_llm: ERROR [internal] load metadata for public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.8 is caused sometimes when building your docker image from the Amazon python base image. To solve this problem, you can update your docker desktop if you haven't done so, restart docker desktop and terminal and then build the image all over again, or if all else fails, first run the command: DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0 docker build . then build your image.
answer_orig:
This error is produced sometimes when building your docker image from the Amazon python base image.
Solution description: The following could solve the problem.
Update your docker desktop if you haven’t done so.
Or restart docker desktop and terminal and then build the image all over again.
Or if all else fails, first run the following command: DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0  docker build .  then build your image.
(optional) Added by Odimegwu David
question: What causes ERROR [internal] load metadata for public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.8?

answer_llm:
To solve the ERROR [internal] load metadata for public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.8 by updating software, you can follow these steps:
1. Update your Docker desktop if you haven't already.
2. Restart Docker desktop and the terminal, then rebuild the image.
3. If all else fails, run the following command before building the image: DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0 docker build .
These steps should help resolve the issue with the Docker image built from the Amazon Python base image.
answer_orig:
This error is produced sometimes when building your docker image from the Amazon python base image.
Solution description: The following could solve the problem.
Update your docker desktop if you haven’t done so.
Or restart docker desktop and terminal and then build the image all over again.
Or if all else fails, first run the following command: DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0  docker build .  then build your image.
(optional) Added by Odimegwu David
question: How can I solve the ERROR [internal] load metadata for public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.8 by updating software?

answer_llm: To fix the metadata loading error after restarting Docker Desktop and terminal has failed, you can try running the command: DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0 docker build . and then build your image again.

answer_llm: To build the Docker image without encountering the metadata error, you should run the command: DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0 docker build . if all other solutions fail.
answer_orig:
This error is produced sometimes when building your docker image from the Amazon python base image.
Solution description: The following could solve the problem.
Update your docker desktop if you haven’t done so.
Or restart docker desktop and terminal and then build the image all over again.
Or if all else fails, first run the following command: DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0  docker build .  then build your image.

answer_llm: If you get 'type InterpreterWrapper is already registered', the solution is to restart the kernel and import only `tflite_runtime.interpreter` as `tflite` instead of importing both `tensorflow` and `tflite_runtime.interpreter` in the same notebook.
answer_orig:
When I run   import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite , I get an error message says “ImportError: generic_type: type "InterpreterWrapper" is already registered!”
Solution description
This error occurs when you import both tensorflow  and tflite_runtime.interpreter  “import tensorflow as tf” and “import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite” in the same notebook.  To fix the issue, restart the kernel and import only tflite_runtime.interpreter " import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite".
Asia Saeed

answer_llm: To solve the issue of 'Windows version might not be up-to-date' when running a Docker build command, make sure that Docker is not stopped by a third-party program.
answer_orig:
Problem description:
In command line try to do $ docker build -t dino_dragon
got this Using default tag: latest
[2022-11-24T06:48:47.360149000Z][docker-credential-desktop][W] Windows version might not be up-to-date: The system cannot find the file specified.
error during connect: This error may indicate that the docker daemon is not running.: Post
.
Solution description:
You need to make sure that Docker is not stopped by a third-party program.
Andrei Ilin

answer_llm: To solve the pip version error while running docker build -t dino-dragon-model, you need to make sure you are using the correct wheel version for your Python environment. This should help resolve the error.

answer_llm: In AWS configuration after installing awscli, the fields required are Access Key ID, Secret Access Key, and Default Region Name. The Default output format can be left as None.
answer_orig:
Problem description:
In video 9.6, after installing aswcli, we should configure it with aws configure . There it asks for Access Key ID, Secret Access Key, Default Region Name and also Default output format. What we should put for Default output format? Leaving it as  None is okay?
Solution description:
Yes, in my I case I left everything as the provided defaults (except, obviously, the Access key and the secret access key)
Added by Bhaskar Sarma

answer_llm: Based on the CONTEXT provided from the FAQ database, your lambda function could be passing local tests but failing on a running docker instance due to the issue of the object of type float32 not being JSON serializable. This error occurs when a model (in this case the dino vs dragon model) returns individual estimation values as numpy float32 values that need to be converted individually to base-Python floats in order to become "serializable". You can fix this by converting individual estimation values to floats in your model's output.
answer_orig:
Problem:
While passing local testing of the lambda function without issues, trying to test the same input with a running docker instance results in an error message like
{‘errorMessage’: ‘Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable’, ‘errorType’: ‘Runtime.MarshalError’, ‘requestId’: ‘f155492c-9af2-4d04-b5a4-639548b7c7ac’, ‘stackTrace’: []}
This happens when a model (in this case the dino vs dragon model) returns individual estimation values as numpy float32 values (arrays). They need to be converted individually to base-Python floats in order to become “serializable”.
Solution:
In my particular case, I set up the dino vs dragon model in such a way as to return a label + predicted probability for each class as follows (below is a two-line extract of function predict() in the lambda_function.py):
preds = [interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0], \
1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]]
In which case the above described solution will look like this:
preds = [float(interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]), \
float(1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0])]
The rest can be made work by following the chapter 9 (and/or chapter 5!) lecture videos step by step.
Added by Konrad Muehlberg
question: Why does my lambda function pass local tests but fail on a running docker instance?

answer_llm: The 'Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable' error in your model occurs when the model returns individual estimation values as numpy float32 values (arrays) that need to be converted to base-Python floats in order to become serializable. Specifically, you need to convert these values individually to base-Python floats, typically done by using the float() function, in order to resolve this error.

question: What causes the 'Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable' error in my model?

answer_llm:
To convert numpy float32 values to be serializable in your serverless application, you need to individually convert them to base-Python floats. This can be done by using the float() function on each value in the numpy array. For example, if you have an array called 'preds' containing float32 values, you can convert them to base-Python floats like this:
preds = [float(value) for value in preds]

Added by Konrad Muehlberg
question: Which chapters and videos should I refer to for resolving lambda function errors in serverless deep learning?

answer_llm: The error when running the `interpreter.set_tensor(input_index, x)` command is caused by the fact that `x` is an integer but a float is expected. To resolve this issue, you need to convert `X` to float32 before setting the tensor using `X = np.float32(X)`.
answer_orig:
I had this error when running the command line : interpreter.set_tensor(input_index, x) that can be seen in the video 9.3 around 12 minutes.
ValueError: Cannot set tensor: Got value of type UINT8 but expected type FLOAT32 for input 0, name: serving_default_conv2d_input:0
This is because the X is an int but a float is expected.
Solution:
I found this solution from this question here https://stackoverflow.com/questions/76102508/valueerror-cannot-set-tensor-got-value-of-type-float64-but-expected-type-float :
# Need to convert to float32 before set_tensor
X = np.float32(X)
Then, it works. I work with tensorflow 2.15.0, maybe the fact that this version is more recent involves this change ?
Added by Mélanie Fouesnard

answer_llm:
To check the size of a file using the Powershell terminal, you can use the following command lines:
$File = Get-Item -Path path_to_file
$FileSize = (Get-Item -Path $FilePath).Length
Now you can check the size of your file, for example in MB:
Write-host "MB":($FileSize/1MB)
answer_orig:
To check your file size using the powershell terminal, you can do the following command lines:
$File = Get-Item -Path path_to_file
$FileSize = (Get-Item -Path $FilePath).Length
Now you can check the size of your file, for example in MB:
Write-host "MB":($FileSize/1MB)
Source: https://www.sharepointdiary.com/2020/10/powershell-get-file-size.html#:~:text=To%20get%20the%20size%20of,the%20file%2C%20including%20its%20size.
Added by Mélanie Fouesnard

answer_llm: To create and push a Docker image for AWS Lambda, you can test the deployment setup locally using AWS RIE (runtime interface emulator). This involves using ports for "docker run" and a certain localhost link for testing. Once your Docker image is built upon the base AWS Lambda image (FROM public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10), you can use the command "docker run -it --rm -p 9000:8080 name" to run the image as a container and start up an endpoint locally at localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations. Then you can post an event to the endpoint using a curl command like 'curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d "{}"'.
answer_orig:
The docker image for aws lambda can be created and pushed to aws ecr and the same can be exposed as a REST API through APIGatewayService in a single go using AWS Serverless Framework. Refer the below article for a detailed walkthrough.

answer_llm:
To resolve the pip install error when building a Docker image in Section 9.5 on an M1 Mac, follow these steps:

1. Use the following link to install tflite runtime for the Docker image:
https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl

2. If the above link doesn't work due to the arm architecture of the M1, you can either build and run the code on a PC or Ubuntu OS.

3. If you still face issues, build the Docker image using the command:
docker build --platform linux/amd64 -t clothing-model .

4. To run the built image, use the command:
docker run -it --rm -p 8080:8080 --platform linux/amd64 clothing-model:latest

These steps should help you resolve the pip install error when building the Docker image on an M1 Mac in Section 9.5.
answer_orig:
Problem:
While trying to build docker image in Section 9.5 with the command:
docker build -t clothing-model .
It throws a pip install error for the tflite runtime whl
ERROR: failed to solve: process "/bin/sh -c pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/blob/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl" did not complete successfully: exit code: 1
Try to use this link: https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl
If the link above does not work:
The problem is because of the arm architecture of the M1. You will need to run the code on a PC or Ubuntu OS.
Or try the code bellow.
Added by Dashel Ruiz Perez
Solution:
To build the Docker image, use the command:
docker build --platform linux/amd64 -t clothing-model .
To run the built image, use the command:
docker run -it --rm -p 8080:8080 --platform linux/amd64 clothing-model:latest
Added by Daniel Egbo

answer_llm: If you encounter a 'Missing Authentication Token' error while testing API Gateway in section 9.7, you need to get the deployed API URL for the specific path you are invoking. For example, the URL structure should look like this: https://<random string>.execute-api.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/test/predict.
answer_orig:
Problem: Trying to test API gateway in 9.7 - API Gateway: Exposing the Lambda Function, running: $ python test.py
With error message:
{'message': 'Missing Authentication Token'}
Solution:
Need to get the deployed API URL for the specific path you are invoking. Example:
https://<random string>.execute-api.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/test/predict
Added by Andrew Katoch

answer_llm: Answer: To resolve the error 'Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement tflite_runtime', you should install Python 3.9 instead of Python 3.10. answer_llm:
To install a specific version of tflite_runtime using pip, you can follow these steps:
1. Check the available versions at https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/.

4. Ensure you are downloading the raw format of the wheel file, not just copying the link.
5. If nothing works, consider using the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development or Docker for testing Lambda.

answer_llm:
To save a Docker image to your local machine, you can use the following command:
docker image save <image-name> -o <name-of-tar-file.tar>
This will export the Docker image to a tar file on your local machine.
answer_orig:
The docker image can be saved/exported to tar format in local machine using the below command:
docker image save <image-name> -o <name-of-tar-file.tar>
The individual layers of the docker image for the filesystem content can be viewed by extracting the layer.tar present in the <name-of-tar-file.tar> created from above.
Sumeet Lalla

answer_llm: If the command aws ecr get-login --no-include-email returns an invalid choice error, you should use the command aws ecr get-login-password instead to resolve the issue.
answer_orig: see here
question: What should I do if the command aws ecr get-login --no-include-email gives an invalid choice error?

answer_llm: To resolve the aws: error: argument operation: Invalid choice error in section 9, use the command: aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com. Alternatively, if you have a default region configured, you can run the command: aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com" as per the AWS documentation.
answer_orig: see here
question: How can I resolve the aws: error: argument operation: Invalid choice error in section 9?

answer_llm:
To find help for the error with the command "aws ecr get-login --no-include-email," you can refer to the AWS documentation: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/docker-push-ecr-image.html. The correct command to use is: 
aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com. Alternatively, you can use the following command without changing anything if you have a default region configured: 
aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com".
This information was added by Humberto Rodriguez.

answer_llm: To sign in to the AWS Console for Week 9: Serverless, you need to log in to the AWS Console. Navigate to IAM by clicking on "Services" in the top left corner, selecting "IAM" under the "Security, Identity, & Compliance" section. Create a new policy by selecting "Policies" in the left navigation pane and clicking on "Create policy." Copy and paste the JSON policy provided earlier for the specific ECR actions. Review and create the policy by providing a name and description, then clicking on "Create policy."
answer_orig:
Sign in to the AWS Console: Log in to the AWS Console.
Navigate to IAM: Go to the IAM service by clicking on "Services" in the top left corner and selecting "IAM" under the "Security, Identity, & Compliance" section.
Create a new policy: In the left navigation pane, select "Policies" and click on "Create policy."
Select the service and actions:
Click on "JSON" and copy and paste the JSON policy you provided earlier for the specific ECR actions.
Review and create the policy:
Click on "Review policy."
Provide a name and description for the policy.
Click on "Create policy."
JSON policy:
{
"Version": "2012-10-17",
"Statement": [
{
"Sid": "VisualEditor0",
"Effect": "Allow",
"Action": [
"ecr:CreateRepository",
"ecr:GetAuthorizationToken",
"ecr:BatchCheckLayerAvailability",
"ecr:BatchGetImage",
"ecr:InitiateLayerUpload",
"ecr:UploadLayerPart",
"ecr:CompleteLayerUpload",
"ecr:PutImage"
],
"Resource": "*"
}
]
}
Added by: Daniel Muñoz-Viveros
ERROR: failed to solve: public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10: error getting credentials - err: exec: "docker-credential-desktop.exe": executable file not found in $PATH, out: ``
(WSL2 system)
Solved: Delete the file ~/.docker/config.json
Yishan Zhan

question: How do I create a new IAM policy?

answer_llm:
In the JSON policy for ECR, the following actions should be included:
- ecr:CreateRepository
- ecr:GetAuthorizationToken
- ecr:BatchCheckLayerAvailability
- ecr:BatchGetImage
- ecr:InitiateLayerUpload
- ecr:UploadLayerPart
- ecr:CompleteLayerUpload
- ecr:PutImage
answer_orig:
Sign in to the AWS Console: Log in to the AWS Console.
Navigate to IAM: Go to the IAM service by clicking on "Services" in the top left corner and selecting "IAM" under the "Security, Identity, & Compliance" section.
Create a new policy: In the left navigation pane, select "Policies" and click on "Create policy."
Select the service and actions:
Click on "JSON" and copy and paste the JSON policy you provided earlier for the specific ECR actions.
Review and create the policy:
Click on "Review policy."
Provide a name and description for the policy.
Click on "Create policy."
JSON policy:
{
"Version": "2012-10-17",
"Statement": [
{
"Sid": "VisualEditor0",
"Effect": "Allow",
"Action": [
"ecr:CreateRepository",
"ecr:GetAuthorizationToken",
"ecr:BatchCheckLayerAvailability",
"ecr:BatchGetImage",
"ecr:InitiateLayerUpload",
"ecr:UploadLayerPart",
"ecr:CompleteLayerUpload",
"ecr:PutImage"
],
"Resource": "*"
}
]
}

answer_llm:
To test AWS Lambda with Docker locally, you can use AWS RIE (runtime interface emulator). Ensure your Docker image is built upon the base AWS Lambda image (FROM public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10). Use the following command to run the image and start an endpoint locally at localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations:

docker run -it --rm -p 9000:8080 name

Then post an event to the endpoint using a curl command. Here are examples of curl testing for both Windows and Unix systems. Additionally, if you encounter an error related to marshaling response types, convert the response in lambda_handler() to a string using str(result).
answer_orig:
This deployment setup can be tested locally using AWS RIE (runtime interface emulator).
Basically, if your Docker image was built upon base AWS Lambda image (FROM public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10) - just use certain ports for “docker run” and a certain “localhost link” for testing:
docker run -it --rm -p 9000:8080 name
This command runs the image as a container and starts up an endpoint locally at:
localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations
Post an event to the following endpoint using a curl command:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{}'
Examples of curl testing:
* windows testing:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d "{\"url\": \"https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg\"}"
* unix testing:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{"url": "https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg"}'
If during testing you encounter an error like this:
# {"errorMessage": "Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable", "errorType": "Runtime.MarshalError", "requestId": "7ea5d17a-e0a2-48d5-b747-a16fc530ed10", "stackTrace": []}
just turn your response at lambda_handler() to string - str(result).
Added by Andrii Larkin

answer_llm: Based on the context provided, you are getting the error 'Unable to import module 'lambda_function': No module named 'tensorflow' when running python test.py because there might be dependencies with the tensorflow library in the code. One common reason for this error is importing tflite from tensorflow. To resolve this, change the import statement from 'import tensorflow.lite as tflite' to 'import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite'.
answer_orig:
Make sure all codes in test.py dont have any dependencies with tensorflow library. One of most common reason that lead the this error is tflite still imported from tensorflow. Change import tensorflow.lite as tflite to import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite

answer_llm: The prerequisites for installing TensorFlow with CUDA support in WSL2 according to the provided resources are to install CUDA on WSL by referring to the CUDA Toolkit Documentation from Nvidia, install TensorFlow with pip, and choose CUDA 11.7 as the Computer Platform option when installing TensorFlow.
answer_orig:
Running a CNN on your CPU can take a long time and once you’ve run out of free time on some cloud providers, it’s time to pay up. Both can be tackled by installing tensorflow with CUDA support on your local machine if you have the right hardware.
I was able to get it working by using the following resources:
CUDA on WSL :: CUDA Toolkit Documentation (nvidia.com)
Install TensorFlow with pip
Start Locally | PyTorch
I included the link to PyTorch so that you can get that one installed and working too while everything is fresh on your mind. Just select your options, and for Computer Platform, I chose CUDA 11.7 and it worked for me.
Added by Martin Uribe

answer_llm:
If you are getting Allocator ran out of memory errors while running TensorFlow on your own machine, you can try adding the following code at the beginning of your notebook:
```
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```
This should help resolve most of the memory issues you are facing.
answer_orig:
If you are running tensorflow on your own machine and you start getting the following errors:
Allocator (GPU_0_bfc) ran out of memory trying to allocate 6.88GiB with freed_by_count=0. The caller indicates that this is not a failure, but this may mean that there could be performance gains if more memory were available.
Try adding this code in a cell at the beginning of your notebook:
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
After doing this most of my issues went away. I say most because there was one instance when I still got the error once more, but only during one epoch. I ran the code again, right after it finished, and I never saw the error again.
Added by Martin Uribe

answer_llm: The error that might occur when creating the virtual environment in session 10.3 with pipenv and running gateway.py is: TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly. This error is due to a version conflict in the protobuf package. To resolve this issue, you can either downgrade the protobuf package to 3.20.x or lower, set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python for slower parsing, or fix the protobuf version to an older one, such as protobuf==3.19.6.
answer_orig:
In session 10.3, when creating the virtual environment with pipenv and trying to run the script gateway.py, you might get this error:
TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.
If this call came from a _pb2.py file, your generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0.
If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, some other possible workarounds are:
1. Downgrade the protobuf package to 3.20.x or lower.
2. Set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python (but this will use pure-Python parsing and will be much slower).
More information: https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/news/2022-05-06#python-updates
This will happen if your version of protobuf is one of the newer ones. As a workaround, you can fix the protobuf version to an older one. In my case I got around the issue by creating the environment with:
pipenv install --python 3.9.13 requests grpcio==1.42.0 flask gunicorn \
keras-image-helper tensorflow-protobuf==2.7.0 protobuf==3.19.6
Added by Ángel de Vicente
question: What error might occur when creating the virtual environment in session 10.3 with pipenv and running gateway.py?

To resolve the TypeError caused by the recent version of protobuf in session 10.3, you can downgrade the protobuf package to version 3.20.x or lower. Alternatively, you can set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python, but note that this method will utilize pure-Python parsing and will run much slower. answer_llm: If WSL cannot connect to the Docker daemon, you can try the following solution: Go to your Docker Desktop settings, click on resources, then click on WSL Integration. Enable additional distros, even if the additional distro is the same as the default WSL distro.
answer_orig:
Due to the uncertainties associated with machines, sometimes you can get the error message like this when you try to run a docker command:
”Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?”
Solution: The solution is simple. The Docker Desktop might no longer be connecting to the WSL Linux distro. What you need to do is go to your Docker Desktop setting and then click on resources. Under resources, click on WSL Integration. You will get a tab like the image below:
Just enable additional distros. That’s all. Even if the additional distro is the same as the default WSL distro.
Odimegwu David
question: What should I do if WSL cannot connect to the Docker daemon?

answer_llm:
To resolve the error "Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?", you can follow different solutions based on the operating system:

1. For WSL: Re-install Docker by removing the Docker installation from WSL and install Docker Desktop on your host machine (Windows).

2. For Linux: Start the Docker daemon with either of the following commands:
   - `sudo dockerd`
   - `sudo service docker start`

3. For WSL with Docker Desktop: Go to Docker Desktop settings, click on resources, then click on WSL Integration. Enable additional distros to ensure proper connection.

Remember to restart Docker services if necessary to resolve any errors related to Docker.

answer_llm:
If the HPA instance doesn't work correctly even after installing the latest Metrics Server, you can run the following command to use a metrics server deployment file already embedding the - --kubelet-insecure-tls option:
kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Peco602/ml-zoomcamp/main/10-kubernetes/kube-config/metrics-server-deployment.yaml. This should help resolve the issue.
answer_orig:
In case the HPA instance does not run correctly even after installing the latest version of Metrics Server from the components.yaml manifest with:
>>kubectl apply -f https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/metrics-server/releases/latest/download/components.yaml
And the targets still appear as <unknown>
Run >>kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
And search for this line:
args:
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Add this line in the middle:  - --kubelet-insecure-tls
So that it stays like this:
args:
- --kubelet-insecure-tls
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Save and run again >>kubectl get hpa
Added by Marilina Orihuela
question: What should be done if the HPA instance doesn't work correctly even after installing the latest Metrics Server?

answer_llm:
To edit the metrics-server deployment and fix the HPA issue, you can run the following command:
>>kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
Search for the line:
args:
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Add the line in the middle: - --kubelet-insecure-tls
Save the changes and run:
>>kubectl get hpa
This should resolve the HPA issue.

- --kubelet-insecure-tls
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Save and run again >>kubectl get hpa
Added by Marilina Orihuela
question: What line should be added to the metrics-server args to fix the HPA target issue?

answer_llm: After editing the metrics-server, you should run the command `kubectl get hpa` to check the HPA status again.
answer_orig:
In case the HPA instance does not run correctly even after installing the latest version of Metrics Server from the components.yaml manifest with:
>>kubectl apply -f https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/metrics-server/releases/latest/download/components.yaml
And the targets still appear as <unknown>
Run >>kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
And search for this line:
args:
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Add this line in the middle:  - --kubelet-insecure-tls
So that it stays like this:
args:
- --kubelet-insecure-tls
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Save and run again >>kubectl get hpa
Added by Marilina Orihuela

answer_llm: To resolve the 'Could not install packages due to an OSError: [WinError 5] Access is denied' error when installing libraries in Windows, you can use the `--user` option with the pip install command. For example, you can run `pip --user install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0` to successfully install the libraries in Windows.
answer_orig:
When I run pip install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0 to install the libraries in windows machine,  I was getting the below error :
ERROR: Could not install packages due to an OSError: [WinError 5] Access is denied: 'C:\\Users\\Asia\\anaconda3\\Lib\\site-packages\\google\\protobuf\\internal\\_api_implementation.cp39-win_amd64.pyd'
Consider using the `--user` option or check the permissions.
Solution description :
I was able to install the libraries using below command:
pip --user install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0

File "C:\Users\Asia\Data_Science_Code\Zoompcamp\Kubernetes\gat.py", line 9, in <module>
from tensorflow_serving.apis import predict_pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow_serving\apis\predict_pb2.py", line 14, in <module>
from tensorflow.core.framework import tensor_pb2 as tensorflow_dot_core_dot_framework_dot_tensor__pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\core\framework\tensor_pb2.py", line 14, in <module>
from tensorflow.core.framework import resource_handle_pb2 as tensorflow_dot_core_dot_framework_dot_resource__handle__pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\core\framework\resource_handle_pb2.py", line 14, in <module>

_message.Message._CheckCalledFromGeneratedFile()
TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.
If this call came from a _pb2.py file, your generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0.
If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, some other possible workarounds are:
1. Downgrade the protobuf package to 3.20.x or lower.

pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1

question: What causes the TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly?

answer_llm:
To resolve the issue of your generated protobuf code being out of date and encountering the error "Descriptors cannot not be created directly", you can follow these steps:

1. Regenerate your generated protobuf code with protoc >= 3.19.0.
2. If immediate regeneration is not possible, you can try downgrading the protobuf package to version 3.20.x or lower.
3. Another workaround is to set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python, but this might result in slower parsing.

In this specific case, the issue was resolved by downgrading protobuf to version 3.20.1 using the command:
pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1.

answer_llm: To install kubectl easily on Windows, you can follow this tutorial: https://medium.com/@ggauravsigra/install-kubectl-on-windows-af77da2e6fff. Download kubectl using curl and execute the command lines provided in the tutorial. Once downloaded, copy the exe file to a specific folder on the C drive. Make sure to add this folder path to PATH in your environment variables. Similarly, Kind can be installed on Windows using the curl command by specifying a folder to be added to the PATH environment variable.
answer_orig:
To install kubectl on windows using the terminal in vscode (powershell), I followed this tutorial: https://medium.com/@ggauravsigra/install-kubectl-on-windows-af77da2e6fff
I first downloaded kubectl with curl, with these command lines: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl-windows/#install-kubectl-binary-with-curl-on-windows
At step 3, I followed the tutorial with the copy of the exe file in a specific folder on C drive.
Then I added this folder path to PATH in my environment variables.
Kind can be installed the same way with the curl command on windows, by specifying a folder that will be added to the path environment variable.
Added by Mélanie Fouesnard

To install kubectl on windows using the terminal in vscode (powershell), I followed this tutorial: https://medium.com/@ggauravsigra/install-kubectl-on-windows-af77da2e6fff
I first downloaded kubectl with curl, with these command lines: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl-windows/#install-kubectl-binary-with-curl-on-windows
At step 3, I followed the tutorial with the copy of the exe file in a specific folder on C drive.
Then I added this folder path to PATH in my environment variables.
Kind can be installed the same way with the curl command on windows, by specifying a folder that will be added to the path environment variable.

answer_llm: To install Kind using choco, you need to first install the choco library. Launch a powershell terminal with administrator privilege and install choco library by running this command: Set-ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Scope Process -Force; [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol -bor 3072; iex ((New-Object System.Net.WebClient).DownloadString('https://chocolatey.org/install.ps1')). Once choco is installed, you can then proceed with installing Kind.

Krishna Anand

answer_llm: To install Kind if you are having issues with Powershell and Choco Library, you can simply install Kind through Go. Download and Install Go, confirm installation by typing 'go version' in Command Prompt, and then proceed by installing Kind with the command 'go install sigs.k8s.io/kind@v0.20.0' followed by confirming the installation with 'kind --version'.
answer_orig:
If you are having challenges installing Kind through the Windows Powershell as provided on the website and Choco Library as I did, you can simply install Kind through Go.
> Download and Install Go (https://go.dev/doc/install)
> Confirm installation by typing the following in Command Prompt -  go version
> Proceed by installing Kind by following this command - go install sigs.k8s.io/kind@v0.20.0
>Confirm Installation kind --version
It works perfectly.

answer_llm:
To resolve the 'connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused' issue with kubectl, you should follow these steps:
1. Delete the cluster with the command kind delete cluster
2. Remove the .kube directory with the command rm -rf ~/.kube
3. Recreate the cluster with the command kind create cluster

After completing these steps, try running the kubectl command again and it should work without the error.
answer_orig:
I ran into an issue where kubectl wasn't working.
I kept getting the following error:
kubectl get service
The connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused - did you specify the right host or port?
I searched online for a resolution, but everyone kept talking about creating an environment variable and creating some admin.config file in my home directory.
All hogwash.
The solution to my problem was to just start over.
kind delete cluster
rm -rf ~/.kube
kind create cluster
Now when I try the same command again:
kubectl get service
NAME         TYPE        CLUSTER-IP   EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)   AGE
kubernetes   ClusterIP   10.96.0.1    <none>        443/TCP   53s
Added by Martin Uribe
question: How can I resolve the 'connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused' issue with kubectl?

answer_llm:
Martin Uribe took the following steps to fix the kubectl server connection issue:
1. Deleted the existing cluster using the command: kind delete cluster
2. Removed the Kubernetes configuration folder: rm -rf ~/.kube
3. Created a new cluster: kind create cluster

After performing these steps, the kubectl command worked without any connection issues.

answer_llm: To solve the issue of running out of storage after building many docker images, you should first remove the unnecessary images using the command "docker rmi," then run "docker system prune" to free up space. Deleting docker images does not actually free up storage space, you need to run the prune command as well.
answer_orig:
Problem description
Due to experimenting back and forth so much without care for storage, I just ran out of it on my 30-GB AWS instance.
My first reflex was to remove some zoomcamp directories, but of course those are mostly code so it didn’t help much.
Solution description
> docker images
revealed that I had over 20 GBs worth of superseded / duplicate models lying around, so I proceeded to > docker rmi
a bunch of those — but to no avail!
It turns out that deleting docker images does not actually free up any space as you might expect. After removing images, you also need to run
> docker system prune
See also: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36799718/why-removing-docker-containers-and-images-does-not-free-up-storage-space-on-wind
Added by Konrad Mühlberg
question: How can I solve the issue of running out of storage after building many docker images?

answer_llm: Removing some zoomcamp directories did not help in freeing up space because those directories mostly contained code, which didn't use up much storage. The real issue was the presence of over 20 GBs worth of superseded/duplicate docker images. Deleting docker images does not automatically free up space, and you also need to run "docker system prune" after removing images to reclaim storage space.

answer_llm: The "m" in CPU values in Kubernetes deployment.yaml files stands for milliCPU, which is a unit of computing power representing one thousandth of a CPU core. It allows for expressing CPU requirements and limits in a more granular way, such as "100m" being equivalent to 0.1 CPU core and "500m" being equivalent to 0.5 CPU core.
answer_orig:
In Kubernetes resource specifications, such as CPU requests and limits, the "m" stands for milliCPU, which is a unit of computing power. It represents one thousandth of a CPU core.
cpu: "100m" means the container is requesting 100 milliCPUs, which is equivalent to 0.1 CPU core.
cpu: "500m" means the container has a CPU limit of 500 milliCPUs, which is equivalent to 0.5 CPU core.
These values are specified in milliCPUs to allow fine-grained control over CPU resources. It allows you to express CPU requirements and limits in a more granular way, especially in scenarios where your application might not need a full CPU core.
Added by Andrii Larkin

answer_llm: To resolve the issue of your kind cluster not finding any nodes after loading a Docker image, you should specify the cluster name using the "-n" flag. For example, you can use the command "kind -n clothing-model load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001" to successfully load the Docker image to your cluster named "clothing-model."
answer_orig:
Problem: Failing to load docker-image to cluster (when you’ved named a cluster)
kind load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
ERROR: no nodes found for cluster "kind"
Solution: Specify cluster name with -n
kind -n clothing-model load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
Andrew Katoch
question: What should I do if my kind cluster can't find any nodes after loading a Docker image?

answer_llm: If 'kind' is not recognized as an internal or external command on Windows, you should rename the executable file kind-windows-amd64.exe to kind.exe. Then, put the file in a specific folder and add it to PATH.
answer_orig:
Problem: I download kind from the next command:
curl.exe -Lo kind-windows-amd64.exe https://kind.sigs.k8s.io/dl/v0.17.0/kind-windows-amd64
When I try
kind --version
I get: 'kind' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file
Solution: The default name of executable is kind-windows-amd64.exe, so that you have to rename this file to  kind.exe. Put this file in specific folder, and add it to PATH
Alejandro Aponte

question: What is the solution when 'kind' is not operable after executing kind --version on Windows?

answer_llm:
To make 'kind' executable once it's downloaded on a Windows machine, you should follow these steps:
1. Download 'kind' using the command:
```
curl.exe -Lo kind-windows-amd64.exe https://kind.sigs.k8s.io/dl/v0.17.0/kind-windows-amd64
```
2. Rename the downloaded file to `kind.exe`.
3. Put the file in a specific folder and add this folder to the PATH environment variable.

Solution: The default name of executable is kind-windows-amd64.exe, so that you have to rename this file to  kind.exe. Put this file in specific folder, and add it to PATH

answer_llm: Solution: The issue is related to versions of Flask and Werkzeug. It appears when using an old version of Werkzeug (2.2.2) with a new version of Flask (2.2.2). To fix this problem, you need to pin the version of Flask to an older version. You can do this by running `pipenv install Flask==2.1.3`.
answer_orig:
Problem Description:
In video 10.3, when I was testing a flask service, I got the above error. I ran docker run .. in one terminal. When in second terminal I run python gateway.py, I get the above error.
Solution: This error has something to do with versions of Flask and Werkzeug. I got the same error, if I just import flask with from flask import Flask.
By running pip freeze > requirements.txt,I found that their versions are Flask==2.2.2 and Werkzeug==2.2.2. This error appears while using an old version of werkzeug (2.2.2) with new version of flask (2.2.2). I solved it by pinning version of Flask into an older version with pipenv install Flask==2.1.3.
Added by Bhaskar Sarma
question: What solution can you offer for the TypeError related to 'unbound_message' when importing Flask?

answer_llm: Based on the context provided in the FAQ database, the TypeError encountered in video 10.3 while running Docker and then running python gateway.py is due to an issue with the version of Flask and Werkzeug being used. The error appears when using an older version of Werkzeug (2.2.2) with a newer version of Flask (2.2.2). To resolve this error, you can pin the version of Flask to an older version by running `pipenv install Flask==2.1.3`.

answer_llm: ANSWER: The solution to the error 'aws: error: argument operation: Invalid choice' while using 'aws ecr get-login --no-include-email' is to use the command 'aws ecr get-login-password' instead. This will simplify the login process and provide you with the password needed for docker login.
answer_orig:
As per AWS documentation:
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/docker-push-ecr-image.html
You need to do: (change the fields in red)
aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com
Alternatively you can run the following command without changing anything given you have a default region configured
aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com"
Added by Humberto Rodriguez

answer_llm: The solution for the TensorFlow Serving error on Apple M1 Mac is to use the "emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest" image instead of the "tensorflow/serving:2.7.0" image.
answer_orig:
While trying to run the docker code on M1:
docker run --platform linux/amd64 -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
tensorflow/serving:2.7.0
It outputs the error:
Error:
Status: Downloaded newer image for tensorflow/serving:2.7.0
[libprotobuf FATAL external/com_google_protobuf/src/google/protobuf/generated_message_reflection.cc:2345] CHECK failed: file != nullptr:
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'google::protobuf::FatalException'
what():  CHECK failed: file != nullptr:
qemu: uncaught target signal 6 (Aborted) - core dumped
/usr/bin/tf_serving_entrypoint.sh: line 3:     8 Aborted                 tensorflow_model_server --port=8500 --rest_api_port=8501 --model_name=${MODEL_NAME} --model_base_path=${MODEL_BASE_PATH}/${MODEL_NAME} "$@"
Solution
docker pull emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest
docker run -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64
See more here: https://github.com/emacski/tensorflow-serving-arm
Added by Daniel Egbo

-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
tensorflow/serving
You get an error:
/usr/bin/tf_serving_entrypoint.sh: line 3:     7 Illegal instruction     tensorflow_model_server --port=8500 --rest_api_port=8501 --model_name=${MODEL_NAME} --model_base_path=${MODEL_BASE_PATH}/${MODEL_NAME} "$@"
Solution:
Use bitnami/tensorflow-serving base image
Launch it either using docker run
docker run -d \
--name tf_serving \
-p 8500:8500 \
-p 8501:8501 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1 \
-e TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model \
bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
Or the following docker-compose.yaml
version: '3'
services:
tf_serving:
image: bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
volumes:
- ${PWD}/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1
ports:
- 8500:8500
- 8501:8501
environment:
- TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model
And run it with
docker compose up
Added by Alex Litvinov

answer_llm:
If HPA doesn’t show CPU metrics, you should follow these steps:
1. Delete HPA by running: kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa
2. Apply the Metrics Server from this link: kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pythianarora/total-practice/master/sample-kubernetes-code/metrics-server.yaml
3. Recreate the HPA. This should resolve the issue with CPU metrics reporting.
answer_orig:
Problem: CPU metrics Shows Unknown
NAME         REFERENCE           TARGETS         MINPODS   MAXPODS   REPLICAS   AGE
credit-hpa   Deployment/credit   <unknown>/20%   1         3         1          18s
FailedGetResourceMetric       2m15s (x169 over 44m)  horizontal-pod-autoscaler  failed to get cpu utilization: unable to get metrics for resource cpu: unable to fetch metrics from resource metrics API:
Solution:
-> Delete HPA (kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa)
-> kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pythianarora/total-practice/master/sample-kubernetes-code/metrics-server.yaml
-> Create HPA
This should solve the cpu metrics report issue.
Added by Priya V

answer_llm: If you encounter errors with Istio during KServe installation, you should edit the "quick_install.bash" file by downloading it without running the bash script. Then, edit the versions of Istio and Knative as per the matrix on the KServe website. After making these changes, you can run the bash script again.
answer_orig:
Problem description:
Running this:
curl -s "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kserve/kserve/release-0.9/hack/quick_install.sh" | bash
Fails with errors because of istio failing to update resources, and you are on kubectl > 1.25.0.
Check kubectl version with kubectl version
Solution description
Edit the file “quick_install.bash” by downloading it with curl without running bash. Edit the versions of Istio and Knative as per the matrix on the KServe website.
Run the bash script now.
Added by Andrew Katoch

answer_llm:
The solution description for the projects includes:
- Think of a problem that's interesting for you and find a dataset for that
- Describe this problem and explain how a model could be used
- Prepare the data and doing EDA, analyze important features

- Export the notebook into a script
- Put your model into a web service and deploy it locally with Docker
- Bonus points for deploying the service to the cloud

answer_llm:
The steps involved in completing the midterm project include:
1. Think of a problem that's interesting for you and find a dataset for that
2. Describe the problem and explain how a model could be used
3. Prepare the data and conduct exploratory data analysis (EDA), analyze important features
4. Train multiple models, tune their performance, and select the best model
5. Export the notebook into a script
6. Put the model into a web service and deploy it locally with Docker
7. Bonus points for deploying the service to the cloud

It's important to note that all midterms and capstones are meant to be solo projects and that project deadlines can be found in the cohort folder for your own cohort's deadline.

answer_llm: To find the projects you need to review for the capstone, you should wait for Alexey and his team to compile a Google sheet with links to submitted projects that are assigned to you for review. You will need to access this sheet and follow the instructions provided to conduct peer reviews within the evaluation deadline.
answer_orig:
I am not sure how the project evaluate assignment works? Where do I find this? I have access to all the capstone 2 project, perhaps, I can randomly pick any to review.
Answer:
The link provided for example (2023/Capstone link ): https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdgoepohpgbM4MWTAHWuXa6r3NXKnxKcg4NDOm0bElAdXdnnA/viewform contains a list of all submitted projects to be evaluated. More specific, you are to review 3 assigned peer projects. In the spreadsheet are 3 hash values of your assigned peer projects. However, you need to derive the your hash value of your email address and find the value on the spreadsheet under the (reviewer_hash) heading.
To calculate your hash value run the python code below:
from hashlib import sha1
def compute_hash(email):
return sha1(email.lower().encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()
# Example usage **** enter your email below (Example1@gmail.com)****
email = "Example1@gmail.com"
hashed_email = compute_hash(email)
print("Original Email:", email)
print("Hashed Email (SHA-1):", hashed_email)
Edit the above code to replace Example1@gmail.com as your email address
Store and run the above python code from your terminal. See below as the Hashed Email (SHA-1) value
You then go to the link: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vR-7RRtq7AMx5OzI-tDbkzsbxNLm-NvFOP5OfJmhCek9oYcDx5jzxtZW2ZqWvBqc395UZpHBv1of9R1/pubhtml?gid=876309294&single=true
Lastly, copy the “Hashed Email (SHA-1): bd9770be022dede87419068aa1acd7a2ab441675” value and search for 3 identical entries. There you should see your peer project to be reviewed.
By Emmanuel Ayeni
question: How do I find the projects I need to review for the capstone?

Once you have the hashed email, go to the spreadsheet link provided to search for 3 identical entries matching your hashed email. This will give you the peer projects that you are assigned to review.

However, you need to derive the your hash value of your email address and find the value on the spreadsheet under the (reviewer_hash) heading.
To calculate your hash value run the python code below:
from hashlib import sha1
def compute_hash(email):
return sha1(email.lower().encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()
# Example usage **** enter your email below (Example1@gmail.com)****
email = "Example1@gmail.com"
hashed_email = compute_hash(email)
print("Original Email:", email)
print("Hashed Email (SHA-1):", hashed_email)
Edit the above code to replace Example1@gmail.com as your email address
Store and run the above python code from your terminal. See below as the Hashed Email (SHA-1) value
You then go to the link: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vR-7RRtq7AMx5OzI-tDbkzsbxNLm-NvFOP5OfJmhCek9oYcDx5jzxtZW2ZqWvBqc395UZpHBv1of9R1/pubhtml?gid=876309294&single=true
Lastly, copy the “Hashed Email (SHA-1): bd9770be022dede87419068aa1acd7a2ab441675” value and search for 3 identical entries. There you should see your peer project to be reviewed.
By Emmanuel Ayeni

answer_llm: I recommend putting the pickle-related class into a separate module and importing it in both the script that saves the model and the script that loads the model to avoid the pickle attribute error when using waitress with your Docker container. This error occurs because waitress loads a different module (__main__) than the one used when the model was saved, causing the attribute error. More detailed information can be found in this link: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules.
answer_orig:
When running a docker container with waitress serving the app.py for making predictions, pickle will throw an error that can't get attribute <name_of_class> on module __main__.
This does not happen when Flask is used directly, i.e. not through waitress.
The problem is that the model uses a custom column transformer class, and when the model was saved, it was saved from the __main__ module (e.g. python train.py). Pickle will reference the class in the global namespace (top-level code): __main__.<custom_class>.
When using waitress, waitress will load the predict_app module and this will call pickle.load, that will try to find __main__.<custom_class> that does not exist.
Solution:
Put the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g. train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g. predict.py)
Note: If Flask is used (no waitress) in predict.py, and predict.py has the definition of the class, When  it is run: python predict.py, it will work because the class is in the same namespace as the one used when the model was saved (__main__).
Detailed info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules
Marcos MJD
question: How can I avoid a pickle attribute error when using waitress with my Docker container?

answer_llm:
QUESTION: What causes pickle to throw an attribute error when running a Docker container with waitress?

ANSWER: The error occurs because pickle will reference a custom column transformer class in the global namespace (__main__) when the model is saved from the __main__ module. When using waitress to serve the app.py, pickle will try to find __main__.<custom_class> which does not exist, resulting in the attribute error. The solution is to put the custom class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model and the script that loads the model. This issue does not occur when Flask is used directly.
answer_orig:
When running a docker container with waitress serving the app.py for making predictions, pickle will throw an error that can't get attribute <name_of_class> on module __main__.
This does not happen when Flask is used directly, i.e. not through waitress.
The problem is that the model uses a custom column transformer class, and when the model was saved, it was saved from the __main__ module (e.g. python train.py). Pickle will reference the class in the global namespace (top-level code): __main__.<custom_class>.
When using waitress, waitress will load the predict_app module and this will call pickle.load, that will try to find __main__.<custom_class> that does not exist.
Solution:
Put the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g. train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g. predict.py)
Note: If Flask is used (no waitress) in predict.py, and predict.py has the definition of the class, When  it is run: python predict.py, it will work because the class is in the same namespace as the one used when the model was saved (__main__).
Detailed info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules
Marcos MJD

answer_llm: Based on the context from the FAQ database, common techniques to handle outliers in a dataset include dataset transformation (e.g. log transformation), clipping high values, and dropping observations.

There are different techniques, but the most common used are the next:
Dataset transformation (for example, log transformation)
Clipping high values
Dropping these observations
Alena Kniazeva
question: What are common techniques to handle outliers?

answer_llm: Yes, dataset transformation can help with outliers in a dataset. Some common techniques include log transformation, clipping high values, and dropping those observations.
answer_orig:
There are different techniques, but the most common used are the next:
Dataset transformation (for example, log transformation)
Clipping high values
Dropping these observations
Alena Kniazeva
question: Can dataset transformation help with outliers?

answer_llm: Clipping high values means setting a threshold and limiting any values above that threshold to be equal to the threshold itself. This is a common technique used to handle outliers in a dataset.
answer_orig:
There are different techniques, but the most common used are the next:
Dataset transformation (for example, log transformation)
Clipping high values
Dropping these observations
Alena Kniazeva
question: What does clipping high values mean?

answer_llm: No, dropping observations is a valid method to handle outliers.

Dropping these observations

answer_llm: Based on the provided context, if Bento fails to import the module 'service' with a 'No module named sklearn' error, the issue can be resolved by modifying the packages list in the bentofile.yaml file to include 'scikit-learn' instead of just 'sklearn'. This should fix the problem.
answer_orig:
I was getting the below error message when I was trying to create docker image using bentoml
[bentoml-cli] `serve` failed: Failed loading Bento from directory /home/bentoml/bento: Failed to import module "service": No module named 'sklearn'
Solution description
The cause was because , in bentofile.yaml, I wrote sklearn instead of scikit-learn. Issue was fixed after I modified the packages list as below.
packages: # Additional pip packages required by the service
- xgboost
- scikit-learn
- pydantic
Asia Saeed

answer_llm: The cause of a long error message with something about sparse matrices and a code 500 error with an empty string output in BentoML could be setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the BentoML model saving stage in train.py. This leads to converting each input to a different sized sparse matrix when the custom object is called in service.py, preventing batching due to inconsistent length. In this case, BentoML model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the BentoML model in train.py.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.
Potential reason: Setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the benotml model saving stage in train.py. This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)
question: What might be the cause of a long error message with something about sparse matrices and a code 500 error with an empty string output in BentoML?

answer_llm: I'm sorry for the issue you're experiencing with getting different sized sparse matrices in BentoML production when using DictVectorizer or OHE during training. The potential reason for this is that when setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training and storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the BentoML model saving stage in train.py, it can lead to each input being converted to a different sized sparse matrix in service.py. This inconsistency in length prevents batching. To address this issue, the batchable setting in BentoML model signatures should be set to False for production when saving the BentoML model in train.py.

question: Which module should be modified to make bentoml production work if DictVectorizer or OHE is set to sparse?

answer_llm: Based on the context, the potential reason for the BentoML container giving a code 500 error with an empty string in the Swagger UI could be setting DictVectorizer or OneHotEncoder to sparse while training and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the BentoML model saving stage in train.py. This leads to converting each input to a different sized sparse matrix when the custom object is called in service.py, causing inconsistency in batch processing lengths. To resolve this issue, batchable should be set to False for production during saving the BentoML model in train.py.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.
Potential reason: Setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the benotml model saving stage in train.py. This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)

answer_llm: If your model is too big to be loaded on GitHub, you can use git-lfs (https://git-lfs.com/) to upload large files to your GitHub repository.
answer_orig:
If your model is too big for github one option is to try and compress the model using joblib. For example joblib.dump(model, model_filename, compress=('zlib', 6) will use zlib to compress the model. Just note this could take a few moments as the model is being compressed.
Quinn Avila

answer_llm: To resolve the unauthorized message when pushing a Docker image to Google Container Registry, you should install the Google Cloud SDK and configure Docker using the command: `gcloud auth configure-docker`. This will ensure you have the necessary permissions to perform the operation.
answer_orig:
When you try to push the docker image to Google Container Registry and get this message “unauthorized: You don't have the needed permissions to perform this operation, and you may have invalid credentials.”, type this below on console, but first install https://cloud.google.com/sdk/docs/install, this is to be able to use gcloud in console:
gcloud auth configure-docker
(Jesus Acuña)

answer_llm: To install tflite_runtime in a pipenv environment, you can try installing Python 3.9 as this version of tflite does not run on Python 3.10. Another option is to check the available versions of tflite_runtime for your system at https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/ and if needed, try installing from this repository or from https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite by using pip install commands like: pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl. If none of these options work, you can use the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development and test Lambda using Docker.
answer_orig:
I am getting this error message when I tried to install tflite in a pipenv environment
Error:  An error occurred while installing tflite_runtime!
Error text:
ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement tflite_runtime (from versions: none)
ERROR: No matching distribution found for tflite_runtime
This version of tflite do not run on python 3.10, the way we can make it work is by install python 3.9, after that it would install the tflite_runtime without problem.
Pastor Soto
Check all available versions here:
https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/
If you don’t find a combination matching your setup, try out the options at
https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite
which you can install as shown in the lecture, e.g.
pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
Finally, if nothing works, use the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development, and use Docker for testing Lambda.
Rileen Sinha (based on discussions on Slack)

answer_llm: To resolve the 'ImageDataGenerator name scipy is not defined' error, you should check that scipy is installed in your environment. answer_llm: The solution if you get an UnidentifiedImageError while testing a model locally on a test-image data is to add ?raw=true after .jpg in the image URL. For example, change the URL from 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg' to 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg?raw=true'.
answer_orig:
In deploying model part, I wanted to test my model locally on a test-image data and I had this silly error after the following command:
url = 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg'
X = preprocessor.from_url(url)
I got the error:
UnidentifiedImageError: cannot identify image file <_io.BytesIO object at 0x7f797010a590>
Solution:
Add ?raw=true after .jpg in url. E.g. as below
url = ‘https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg?raw=true’
Bhaskar Sarma

answer_llm: Based on the context provided, if you see `[pipenv.exceptions.ResolutionFailure]` while running `pipenv install`, you likely have a mismatch in your sub-dependencies. To fix this problem, you should manually change the `Pipfile` and `Pipfile.lock` files and then run `pipenv lock`. This should resolve the issue with the dependencies.
answer_orig:
Problem: If you run pipenv install and get this message. Maybe manually change Pipfile and Pipfile.lock.

Alejandro Aponte
question: What should I do if I see [pipenv.exceptions.ResolutionFailure] while running pipenv install?

answer_llm: If you receive the error `pipenv.exceptions.ResolutionFailure`: Warning: Your dependencies could not be resolved. You likely have a mismatch in your sub-dependencies` when using pipenv, you can fix this problem by running `pipenv lock` to synchronize the Pipfile and Pipfile.lock files.
answer_orig:
Problem: If you run pipenv install and get this message. Maybe manually change Pipfile and Pipfile.lock.
Solution: Run: ` pipenv lock` for fix this problem and dependency files
Alejandro Aponte
question: Why might my dependencies not resolve when using pipenv?

answer_llm:
To manually change Pipfile and Pipfile.lock to resolve dependency issues, you can follow these steps:
- Run `pipenv lock` to update the Pipfile.lock file. If that doesn't work,
- In Docker container, use `RUN pipenv install --system --deploy --ignore-pipfile` command to update the dependencies.
- If you encounter a resolution failure warning, you may need to run `pipenv lock` to fix the problem.
- If your Pipfile.lock is out of date during Docker build, you can either delete the Pipfile.lock and rebuild it using `pipenv lock`, or remove the pipenv environment and Pipfile/Pipfile.lock and create a new one.
- If you get a Python_version and Python_full_version error after running `pipenv install`, open Pipfile in a text editor, delete either the python_version or python_full_version line, save the changes, and run `pipenv lock` to create a new Pipfile.lock.

Alejandro Aponte

answer_llm: Based on the context provided in the FAQ database, `dv.get_feature_names()` doesn't work because this function will be deprecated soon. The solution is to change the line `dv.get_feature_names()` to `list(dv.get_feature_names_out())`.
answer_orig:
Problem: In the course this function worked to get the features from the dictVectorizer instance: dv.get_feature_names(). But in my computer did not work. I think it has to do with library versions and but apparently that function will be deprecated soon:
Old: https://scikit-learn.org/0.22/modules/generated/sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.html#sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.get_feature_names
New: https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.html#sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.get_feature_names
Solution: change the line dv.get_feature_names() to list(dv.get_feature_names_out))
Ibai Irastorza
question: Why doesn't dv.get_feature_names() work on my computer?

answer_llm: Yes, library versions can affect the dv.get_feature_names() function. It is deprecated in version 1.0 and will be removed in version 1.2. Instead, you should use the method ".get_feature_names_out()" from DictVectorizer function to resolve the warning.
